title.text: Discourse Annotation and Semantic Annotation in the GNOME Corpus

abstractContent.text: The GNOME corpus was created to study the discourse and semantic properties of discourse entities that affect their realization and interpretation, and particularly salience.
We discuss what information was annotated and the methods we followed.

introductionContent.text: The GNOME corpus was created to study the aspects of discourse that appear to affect generation, especially salience ().
Particular attention was paid to the factors affecting the generation of pronouns (Pearson et al.,;), demonstratives (Poesio and Nygren-Modjeska, To appear) possessives) and definites in general.
These results, and the annotated corpus, were used in the development of both symbolic and statistical natural language generation algorithms for sentence planning), aggregation) and text planning).

The empirical side of the project involved both psychological experiments and corpus annotation, based on a scheme based on the MATE proposals, as well as on a detailed annotation manual, the reliability of whose instructions was tested by extensive experiments).

More recently, the corpus has also been used to develop and evaluate anaphora resolution systems, with a special focus on the resolution of bridging references Although the results of the studies using the GNOME corpus mentioned above have been published in a number of papers, and although a detailed annotation manual was written and has been available on the Web fora few years), none of the previously published papers discusses in detail the goals of the annotation and the methodology that was followed, especially for the non-anaphoric aspects.
In this paper we discuss the methods used to identify possible 'utterances,' the properties of NPs and discourse entities that were annotated, and (very briefly) anaphoric information.
